headline: Dems eye voting rights fight, filibuster changes
sentences: The panel has “gathered thousands of records from state officials and interviewed a slate of witnesses as it attempts to retrace Trump’s attempts to subvert the 2020 election, particularly in four key states that swung the presidency to Biden.” The documents sent to the committee, obtained by POLITICO, “underscore the depth of Trump’s pressure campaign directed at the typically lower-level administrators of presidential balloting.

The emails, texts and phone recordings also add consequential context to previously reported incidents, such as Trump’s call to Georgia's top elections investigator and Mark Meadows’ outreach to Georgia election officials.”
HUDDLE HOTDISH
Ordering a Bite…The House’s office of the Chief Administrative Officer tells Huddle that the Bite app, which we reported on last week, has gotten widespread use since launching on the Hill.

Dems eye voting rights fight, filibuster changes
By KATHERINE TULLY-MCMANUS
01/10/2022 07:29 AM EST
Presented by
DEMS DIG IN — Senate Democrats are expected to force another vote on elections and voting rights legislation as soon as this week, despite not having enough votes to pass the measure.

SANCTIONS IN THE PIPELINE — The Senate is expected to vote this week on legislation from Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) that would require the Biden administration to impose sanctions on the Nord Stream 2 pipeline that carries natural gas from Russia to Germany.

Reality Check: There is not consensus within the 50-vote Democratic caucus on changing the filibuster and Democrats haven’t unveiled a proposal for how they plan to change Senate rules, despite Schumer’s promises to take the issue to the floor.

The Office of the Attending Physician “directs the use of N95 or KN95 masks by all individuals on the House Floor, regardless of vaccination status” and House leaders are telling members to exit the floor immediately after casting their votes.

He was previously Deputy Chief of Staff/Legislative Director for Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.)
TODAY IN CONGRESS
The House convenes at 6:30 p.m. for a quorum call to establish a quorum in the House for the second session of the 117th Congress.

The president is expected to try and build support among the public for voting rights legislation and make the arguments that the Senate needs to pass a voting rights bill, even if they have to change the chamber’s rules to accomplish that.

Johnson’s move, announced in an op-ed in The Wall Street Journal over the weekend (but reported by POLITICO on Friday), will defy his past two-term pledge and set up a major test of Republicans' effort to retake the Senate majority.

If Republicans block the bill — which is expected — Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) has repeatedly vowed to launch an effort to change the Senate’s filibuster rules by Martin Luther King Jr. Day on Jan. 17.

There are proposals under discussion from a carveout from filibuster rules to a return to the talking filibuster or a shift from requiring 60 votes to break a filibuster to requiring 41 "no" votes to sustain it.

Democrats say they don’t want to undercut Biden as he navigates precarious talks with Russia over its possible invasion of Ukraine, and they don’t want to do anything that would undermine trans-Atlantic unity.

Joe Manchin (W.Va.) and Kyrsten Sinema (Ariz.) are the Democratic holdouts on filibuster changes, but Democratic colleagues are aiming to find a proposal that could garner their support.
